headline: Corrections & Amplifications
summary: Corrections  & Amplifications

headline: CD Yields Turn Downward
summary: Yields on certificates of deposit were mostly lower in the latest week.

headline: Let the Sponsorships Begin
summary: There's still 869 days to go before the flame is lit in London's Olympic stadium. But for sponsors, the race to make an impression is already under way.

headline: Pataki Endorses Lazio in New York Governor's Race
summary: Former New York Gov. George Pataki endorsed Republican gubernatorial hopeful Rick Lazio, saying he is the "right person" to reverse the state's downward spiral.

headline: Illinois Blocks Anheuser Bid
summary: The Illinois Liquor Control Commission blocked a bid by Anheuser-Busch Inbev's U.S. division to buy control of its largest Chicago beer distributor. The brewer filed a lawsuit challenging the ruling.

headline: Tip of the day
summary: Indian Premier League odds

headline: Community Health Centers and Abortion
summary: The opinion piece by Charmaine Yoest, CEO of Americans United for Life, ("Abortion And the Health Bill," March 5) includes an incorrect assertion regarding the funding for Community Health Centers in the Senate health-care reform bill. Community Health Centers do not provide abortions.

headline: Steven J. Law: Organized Labor and Citizens United
summary: Unions were the big winners in the 'corporate' free speech case.

headline: Reid Intensifies High-Court Criticism
summary: Long-simmering resentment between the conservative Supreme Court and Democrats approached a boil, as Reid criticized Chief Justice Roberts and his fellow conservatives for striking down limits on corporate political spending.

headline: Financials Lead Stocks Higher
summary: Stocks edged higher thanks to a rally in the financial sector led by AIG and Citigroup, which conducted a successful offering of $2 billion in securities.

headline: CA to Buy Nimsoft for $350 Million
summary: CA said it would pay $350 million in cash to acquire privately-held Nimsoft, a move underscoring the business software maker's efforts to expand its sales with smaller and mid-sized companies.

headline: Verizon to Have 4G Handset in 2011
summary: Verizon Wireless expects to offer its first next-generation 4G handset in mid-2011, about six months earlier than the company had said before.

headline: UC Students: Noble Crusaders or Spoiled Consumers?
summary: William McGurn's recent column makes a lot of bold claims in its dismissal of concerns over student fee hikes at public universities in California yet manages to ignore all the evidence that shows that the systematic defunding of higher education hinders economic growth ("California Students Complain About 'Tax Hikes,' " Main Street, March 2).

headline: Avoiding the Greek Experience
summary: The economic bedlam in Greece as described by David Malpass in "The Euro's Greek Tragedy, and Its Lessons for America" (op-ed, Feb. 27) is an extreme version of a fiscal virus that periodically plagues all western democracies.

headline: Friendship Only Goes So Far in Conflicts
summary: Regarding Joseph W. Ralston's "Why the Pentagon Needs Friends in Beijing" (op-ed, March 5):  When I was an undergraduate at a university in Indiana, I had a Chinese roommate. Part of his family lived in Hong Kong, the majority lived in the People's Republic of China. I was in the U.S. Air Force ROTC program.

headline: A Way to End the Evil Of Gerrymandering
summary: There is a fix to gerrymandering (Letters, March 8). Let each party draw up a separate redistricting plan and let a coin toss choose the winner. Because neither will know the winner in advance, they both will have to hedge their bets and draw the lines more fairly. True, it's left to a coin, but can that be any worse than the system we have now?:

headline: U.K. Shares Strike High For the Year
summary: European stocks rose Wednesday, with an upbeat session on Wall Street providing support after stronger-than-expected economic data from China and the U.S.

headline: Tropicana Raising Prices
summary: Tropicana is shrinking the size of its Pure Premium orange juice jug and raising by 5%-8% the price of its gallon containers, due to the freeze that hurt Florida's orange crop.

headline: Times Has (Some) Praise for National Enquirer Breaking Edwards' Story It Ignored
summary: From the Media Research Center

headline: Sebelius Warns Health Insurers
summary: HHS Secretary Sebelius sketched out a stark choice for health insurers: oppose reform and eventually lose customers, or work with the White House to improve the legislation.

headline: U.S. Monthly Budget Deficit Balloons
summary: The U.S. government ran its largest ever monthly budget deficit in February as the country's fiscal year-to-date deficit ballooned more than 10% to a record of $651.60 billion.

headline: European Markets Finish Higher
summary: European stocks closed higher, with an upbeat session on Wall Street providing support after stronger-than-expected economic data from China and the U.S.

headline: Terra Now Favors Deal With CF
summary: Yara's board is expected to meet Thursday to discuss whether to continue its takeover bid for fertilizer maker Terra, which said it now favors an offer by CF.

headline: Student-Loan Bill May Enter Health-Care Mix
summary: Democratic leaders are weighing whether to add sweeping higher-education legislation to the second of two health-care bills expected to come before the House in coming weeks.

headline: Gold Prices Take a Beating
summary: Gold futures fell sharply as speculators were exiting from positions in which they had previously bought, with the decline accelerating on preplaced orders triggered when certain prices are hit.

headline: Oil Gets a Lift From Supply Data
summary: Crude settled at an eight-week high after the Energy Information Administration reported larger-than-expected drops in fuel inventories, along with a slight increase in demand for oil products.

headline: Navigating the Art of the L.A. River
summary: "The Ulysses Guide to the Los Angeles River," now on view at the Pasadena Museum of California Art, gives a detailed look at Los Angeles's waterways and cultural identity, as seen through the eyes of around 25 local artists. Here's a look at the exhibit, which is on view until May 30.

headline: Barclays Plans Swiss Expansion
summary: Barclays plans to start trading operations in Switzerland and is hiring Swiss franc currency traders, people familiar with the situation said Wednesday.

headline: Tech Start-ups Cope With Data Flood
summary: A number of technology companies on the Next Big Thing list aim to help businesses deal with data overload.

headline: Sotheby's Tailors Auction Marketing
summary: The theme of promotional materials for a sale of Qing dynasty antiquities targeted to Chinese collectors is "Imperial Power." For Western buyers: "Objects of Contemplation."

headline: Euro Zone Recovery Still Weak
summary: Industrial data show that the economic recovery in the euro zone remains feeble and prone to setbacks, despite an industrial pickup in France and Italy.

headline: Bill Targets Banks' High-Risk Trades
summary: Two senators introduced legislation echoing calls from the Obama administration to bar taxpayer-insured banks, their affiliates and subsidiaries from engaging in proprietary trading.

headline: AIG Shares Jump Again
summary: The stock continued its impressive gains this month, tacking on another double-digit gain early Wednesday amid heavy trading volumes.

headline: A Tale of Two Insurers
summary: While Prudential PLC earns plaudits for its bold acquisition in Asia, another U.K. insurer, Resolution, has limped quietly out of the FTSE100 after failing to live up to its deal-making ambitions.

headline: American Eagle Profit Soars
summary: Teen and young adult clothing retailer American Eagle Outfitters reported earnings surged 81% on higher sales and margin gains due to less discounting.

headline: Brown-Forman's Profit Drops
summary: The spirits maker posted a decline in its third-quarter earnings, hampered by a trademark impairment, but the company's sales rose 9.9%.

headline: Madonna, Iconix in Joint Venture
summary: Madonna entered a joint venture with Iconix Brand Group to use the entertainer's name and personality in connection with apparel, footwear and other products.

headline: New Securities Issues
summary: The following were among recent offerings and pricings in U.S. and non-U.S. capital markets, with terms and syndicate manager, based on information provided by Dow Jones Newswires and Factiva.

headline: Anil Kumar: What Indian Acquirers Want
summary: As the economy picks up, companies are starting to look for new M&A opportunities.

headline: Los Angeles Leans on BNY Mellon
summary: Hurt by an interest-rate bet gone wrong, Los Angeles is demanding that Bank of New York Mellon renegotiate the deal or face exclusion from any future business.

headline: Turkey Well-Placed to Face Challenges
summary: As Greece continues to call for support to deal with its crisis, Turkey has signaled that it plans to face its problems on its own. Its prospects in doing so look brighter than for many developed markets.

headline: Goldman's Fred Hu to Retire
summary: The Greater China chairman for Goldman Sachs and one of its longest-serving China executives is leaving his post at the Wall Street bank.

headline: Medtronic Brain Stimulator Missed Study Goal
summary: The FDA said a study looking at Medtronic's "deep-brain stimulation" system in epilepsy patients failed to meet a study goal looking at a reduction in the seizure rate over a three-month period.

headline: SNB to Weigh Franc Fears Against Inflation
summary: The Swiss National Bank could start setting the stage for rising interest rates at its forthcoming quarterly policy meeting, but its worries about inflation are jarring with its urge to prevent investors from pushing the Swiss franc higher.

headline: To Motivate Staffers, Are Carrots Better Than Sticks?
summary: To be a great leader, you must understand your followers. What motivates them? What do they want? What do they fear?

headline: How Much Does Pay Matter?
summary: How important is pay to achieving organizational greatness? Not as important as you might think.

headline: Deal Close for Tullow Assets
summary: China's Cnooc and French oil major Total are each expected to acquire a third of Tullow Oil's oil assets in Uganda.

headline: Big Oil Comes to Uganda
summary: Finding oil is one thing. Bringing it to market is another. In the case of Tullow Oil's big Ugandan oil and gas discovery, the difference is up to $10 billion in likely downstream and upstream investment.

headline: U.S. Fetches $15.4 Million for Bank's Warrants
summary: The U.S. government sold its warrants to purchase shares of Washington Federal stock for $15.4 million, the Treasury said.

headline: Greece Still Has Lots to Prove
summary: The successful sale of â‚¬5 billion of 10-year bonds last week may have bought the Greek government some breathing space, but it still has some way to go before it can borrow at an interest rate that will allow it to cut its budget deficit.

headline: Banning CDS Trade Won't Help Greece
summary: In the eyes of European Union officials, the credit default swaps market has emerged as a popular scapegoat in the saga surrounding Greece's debt woes. They may have a point.

headline: Portugal Raises $1.35 Billion
summary: Portugal raised $1.35 billion in a key bond auction, suggesting the government's austerity plan is easing market concerns about the country's ability to pay off its high debts.

headline: Wholesale Inventories Drop
summary: U.S. wholesalers' inventories unexpectedly fell 0.2% in January, as surging demand pulled goods off shelves in the first month of the year.

headline: China Climate Chief Criticizes U.S.
summary: China's chief climate official called for the U.S to do more in providing financing and technology in the global fight against climate change, as international negotiators struggle to find a mutually acceptable way of tackling the problem.

headline: Children's Place Profit Drops 12%
summary: Retailer Children's Place reported a 12% drop in earnings on fewer tax benefits and updated its full-year guidance.

headline: Brown Sets U.K. Budget Date
summary: The British prime minister, whose government is under intense pressure to clarify plans for reducing ballooning debt, said a budget would be laid out on March 24, paving the way for a national election.

headline: OPEC Lifts Oil Demand Forecast
summary: World oil demand is projected to grow by 900,000 barrels per day in 2010, OPEC said, revising up its previous month's forecast while cautioning that the increase is hinged on a sustained global economic rebound, particularly in the U.S.

headline: Airlines Offer to Cede Slots
summary: The European Commission said British Airways, American Airlines and Iberia have offered to lease four pairs of daily take-off and landing slots to competitors on specific trans-Atlantic routes in a bid to push through their bid to gain antitrust immunity.

headline: Thailand Holds Rates Steady
summary: Thailand's central bank held its benchmark interest rate steady as widely expected, but hinted at an increase at its next meeting if domestic political tensions don't interrupt economic growth.

headline: India, Women and Democracy
summary: India is trying to roll back freedoms in the name of helping women.

headline: Michael Auslin: An Obama Freedom Agenda for Asia
summary: The United States should embrace Asia's budding democracies.

headline: German Bishops to Examine Abuse
summary: The German Bishops Conference will lead an investigation into all allegations of sexual and physical abuse of students in Germany.

headline: Harmony Suspends Operations After Death
summary: The South African gold-mining company suspended operations at the No. 8 shaft of its Evander mine after an employee was killed by falling rock.

headline: Australian Debt Market Springs to Life
summary: The market saw a succession of bond offers, including the first by a nonfinancial corporate since the middle of last year, illustrating the recovery in credit markets is continuing apace.

headline: Newspapers Publish Prophet Drawing
summary: At least three Swedish newspapers published a cartoon depicting the Prophet Muhammad with the body of a dog after an alleged plot to murder the artist who created it was uncovered in Ireland.

headline: Woman Charged for Terror Recruiting
summary: A Pennsylvania woman was charged with using the Internet to recruit jihadist fighters and help terrorists overseas.

headline: Northern Rock Loan Surges
summary: Northern Rock, the mortgage lender nationalized by the U.K. government after its near-collapse, said its net loss narrowed in 2009, while its government loan rose sharply.

headline: NMDC Share Sale Off to a Slow Start
summary: The follow-on public offering of state-run iron ore miner NMDC got off to a slow start, receiving bids for only 17% of the total shares on sale, data on the National Stock Exchange showed.

headline: SBI May Test Waters With Retail Bonds
summary: State Bank of India is planning to issue bonds to retail investors for the first time, testing an alternate way to raise funds when the market's capacity to absorb debt may be crimped by the government's record borrowing program.

headline: Cornering The Market On Rubber
summary: The OPEC of rubber? The International Rubber Consortium, a cartel of the world's three largest natural rubber exporters has asked Vietnam to join the club.

headline: Investors Approve Daewoo Stake Sale
summary: Financial investors in Daewoo Engineering unanimously accepted a revised offer from a private equity fund for their stake in the builder, paving the way for its restructuring.

headline: Australia May Revisit Health Plan
summary: Senate's rejection of plan to trim concessions for wealthy adds to speculation that the government will call an early election.

headline: Jindal Steel Committed to Bolivia Project
summary: Jindal Steel & Power is committed to its mining and steel plant project in Bolivia, said a senior company executive, even as the government of the Latin American country turned up the heat on the Indian company, asking it to start building a planned massive steel complex or face losing the deal.

headline: Essar in Talks With Shell to Buy Refineries
summary: India's Essar Oil said it is still in talks with Royal Dutch Shell to buy three refineries in Europe, dismissing a local media report that the two companies had put the negotiations on the back burner.

headline: Standard Life May List Indian Joint Venture
summary: U.K. insurer Standard Life said it may list its Indian joint venture HDFC Standard Life Insurance in the next couple of years.

headline: Tokyo Exchange Warns Fujitsu
summary: Fujitsu said it received a verbal warning from the Tokyo Stock Exchange regarding a change in the explanation of its former president's resignation.

headline: Gensler Calls for New CDS Rules
summary: The CFTC chairman said the U.S. could adopt new regulations for credit-default swaps, the derivative often blamed for the near-collapse of AIG during the financial crisis.

headline: U.S. Scientist: Developing Nations to Adopt GM Crops Faster
summary: Developing countries led by China and Brazil will overtake rich nations in adopting genetically modified crops over the next two-three years, as they strive to raise yields to meet demand from their growing population, Clive James, chairman of the U.S.-based International Service For the Acquisition of Agri-biotech Applications, said.

headline: Thermax Signs Pact With Babcock & Wilcox
summary: India's Thermax said it has signed a joint venture pact with U.S.-based Babcock & Wilcox Power Generation Group to design, make and supply equipment to the Indian electricity sector.

headline: Cable Companies Petition FCC
summary: Cable operators are petitioning the FCC to prohibit broadcasters from yanking channels during fee negotiations, as happened in the recent Cablevision-Disney dispute over ABC.

headline: Apollo Signs Citigroup Deal
summary: Apollo's purchase of Citigroup's real-estate investment business would give Joseph Azrack a second tour of duty.

headline: The Buy Boeing Provision
summary: A botched tanker bid is bad for taxpayers, and American airmen.

headline: Barclays on the Hunt in the U.S.
summary: The U.K. bank is seeking a retail lender that would give it more deposits and extend the presence of Barclays Capital in the U.S.

headline: Businesses Buy Ads vs. Health Overhaul
summary: Some big U.S. business groups announced a multimillion-dollar TV ad campaign aimed at defeating the Democrats' health-care legislation.

headline: A Better Vintage of Tap Water
summary: Manufacturers are pitching a bevy of new products that filter water in the home promising to deliver everything from safer sipping and bathing, to more youthful skin.

headline: Notable & Quotable
summary: James Taranto on Britain's NHS.

headline: Women Customers Power Shoppers Stop
summary: India's Shoppers Stop retailer says new magazines, television shows and movies glorifying glamour have spurred buying of Western clothes and beauty products by women.

headline: Fed Debates Next Rate Signal
summary: Long before the Fed raises short-term interest rates in the face of an improving economy, it will need to signal to the public that a change is in the works. Fed officials are intensifying discussions about how to send that sign when the time comes.

headline: European REIT Rollout at Hand
summary: With European property markets beginning to recover from the market downturn and global recession, there are signs that the REIT revolution could be at hand.

headline: Mary Kissel: Climate Change 'Quagmire'
summary: Why India's environment minister doesn't like Al Gore's approach to global warming.

headline: More March Madness?
summary: CBS says an expanded NCAA tournament would likely require a second broadcaster. Meanwhile, Mark Cuban is interested in data on NBA referees, and David Beckham prepares to face Manchester United.

headline: U.K.: Devaluation No Balm
summary: The debate over the troubles faced by Greece, Portugal, Spain and Ireland in rebalancing their economies has focused on their inability to devalue. The U.K.'s latest data may suggest otherwise.

headline: Swaps Are Under Fire
summary: Momentum is building for stricter oversight of derivatives trading, as a top U.S. regulator recommended new limits on credit-default swaps and European leaders pushed for a ban on speculative bets against government debt.
